body_text.text: The first vertebrates emerged more than 500 Ma (Shu et al. 1999;Hedges 2009), and this was paralleled by embryonic novelties, such as the neural crest mainly contributing to craniofacial morphogenesis.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The genetic basis underlying these morphological novelties is not fully understood, but increasing sequence data is providing clues to these questions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In particular, recent genome-wide analyses provided convincing evidence of two rounds (2R) of whole-genome duplication (WGD) early in vertebrate evolution (Lundin 1993;Holland et al. 1994;Sidow 1996;Dehal and Boore 2005;Putnam et al. 2008).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: As a result, the common pattern obtained in phylogenetic analyses of typical gene families is a "four-toone" relationship in which maximally four vertebrate paralogs are co-orthologs of a single invertebrate proto-ortholog.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Among vertebrate lineages, the teleost fishes are characterized by their further derived genomes because of a third round of WGD, the so-called teleost-specific genome duplication (TSGD; Amores et al. 1998;Wittbrodt et al. 1998; reviewed in Meyer and Van de Peer 2005).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Postduplication processes, such as neo-or subfunctionalization, based on the initially redundant set of genes, utilized this initial abundance of genetic raw material for further diversification (Ohno 1970;Force et al. 1999).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The redundancy introduced by the 2R-WGD might thus have triggered vertebrate novelties, such as a well-organized brain compartment (Manning and Scheeff 2010).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In addition to the surplus of genomic elements resulting from the 2R-WGD, de novo genes (also often referred to as taxonomically restricted genes or new genes; Khalturin et al. 2009) introduced at the vertebrate origin could have contributed to the vertebrate-specific gene repertoire.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A study focusing on genome-wide information of the sea lamprey (Petromyzon marinus), an outgroup to jawed vertebrates, revealed 224 protein-coding genes that are unique to vertebrates (Smith et al. 2013).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The target of this study, ectodermal neural cortex (ENC) genes, has been identified only in vertebrates, but they share the conserved BTB/POZ domain and kelch repeats with the rest of the BTB/POZ-kelch repeat superfamily members.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The fact that kelch repeat-containing genes are present throughout bilaterians implies that a proto-ENC gene dates back to the last common ancestor of protostomes and deuterostomes (Prag and Adams 2003).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The kelch repeat superfamily to which the ENC genes belong is characterized by four to seven tandem repeats of~50 amino acid motif in a peptide (Bork and Doolittle 1994;Adams et al. 2000).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Amino acid sequences between motifs are weakly conserved, except for a few key residues ( fig. 1A).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This low level of conservation in amino acid sequences impeded a reliable survey of the complete superfamily (Adams et al. 2000).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Despite the divergent amino acid sequence, they all presumably form antiparallel b-sheets that together assemble a bpropeller (Adams et al. 2000).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The structural subgroup of the kelch repeat superfamily to which ENC genes belong is additionally characterized by an N-terminal BTB/POZ (Broad-Complex, Tramtrack, and Bric-a-brac/Poxvirus and Zinc-finger) domain of approximately 120 amino acids (Godt et al. 1993; Bardwell and Treisman 1994).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This domain is responsible for protein-protein interactions and allows this class of proteins to dimerize (Bardwell and Treisman 1994;Albagli et al. 1995).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Proteins encoded by members of the kelch repeat superfamily are implicated in diverse biological processes, and their cellular localizations differ between intracellular compartments, cell surface, and extracellular milieu.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Products of several members of this superfamily, including ENC1, have been shown to associate with actin cytoskeleton (Xue and Cooley 1993;Hernandez et al. 1997).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Li et al. (2007) identified ENC1, among others, as suitable phylogenetic marker because it is qualified by the presence of one single coding exon, which facilitates polymerase chain reaction (PCR) amplification with genomic DNA (gDNA).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: ENC1 as a phylogenetic marker has been employed in numerous phylogenetic studies of actinopterygian fish (e.g., notothenioid fishes [Matschiner et al. 2011], sticklebacks [Kawahara et al. 2009], and ray-finned fishes [Li et al. 2008]) as well as reptiles (iguanian lizards [Townsend et al. 2011] and other squamates [Wiens et al. 2010]).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Hernandez et al. (1997) reported for the first time developmental roles of an ENC gene, namely those of ENC1 in the nervous system of mouse.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: ENC1 is expressed in a dynamic manner from early gastrulation on throughout neural development and persists in the adult nervous system (Hernandez et al. 1997).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A study on various human cell lines suggested that ENC1 is involved in the differentiation of neural crest cells and is down-regulated in neuroblastoma tumors (Hernandez et al. 1998).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Interestingly, an antisense transcript of its first exon, ENC1-AS, is linked to a certain type of leukemia (Hammarsund et al. 2004).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Except for mammalian ENC1, only sparse information on the developmental roles of the ENC gene family is available.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The expression patterns of chicken ENC1 in the developing telencephalon were characterized in great detail and resemble the dynamic pattern in mouse (Garcia-Calero and Puelles 2009).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Expression patterns of the full set of ENC genes (ENC1, -2, and -3) have been investigated only in one species, the amphibian Xenopus laevis (Haigo et al. 2003).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The only expression data of ENC genes outside tetrapods are reports of enc3 in developing zebrafish (Kudoh et al. 2001;Thisse B and Thisse C 2004;Thisse C and Thisse B 2005;Bradford et al. 2011; available on the ZFIN database: http://zfin.org/, last accessed July 24, 2013; Qian et al. 2013).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In this study, our exhaustive gene and taxon sampling revealed the diversification pattern of the ENC gene family in a higher resolution.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Conserved synteny between genomic regions containing ENC1, -2, and -3 suggested the triplication through 2R-WGDs early in vertebrate evolution.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Of those, the ENC3 ortholog was shown to have been lost in the eutherian lineage.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: We also provide the first report of expression patterns of nontetrapod ENC1 in a catshark and of the complete set of enc genes (enc1, -2, and -3) in zebrafish.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Overall, molecular and regulatory evolution of the ENC genes within vertebrates conform to typical patterns hitherto observed for many other gene families including developmental regulatory genes, except for one aspect: Conventional molecular phylogenetic methods could not identify the invertebrate orthologs of ENC genes.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Because the ENC gene family is one of the numerous subfamilies in the kelch repeat superfamily widely possessed by bilaterians, nonidentification of this long-standing gene in invertebrate indicates unique evolutionary trajectory of the ENC gene family.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: Unexpectedly, a protein of a plant, Ipomoea trifida (EU366607 in GenBank), was placed inside the group of teleost ENC1 genes and was found to cluster with stickleback ENC1 (bootstrap support in the ML analysis, 79; data not shown).
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: This placement is in stark contrast to the generally accepted species phylogeny, and therefore we conclude that a contamination of a teleost sequence is the most likely explanation.
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: On the basis of our molecular phylogenetic analysis, we suggest the new gene names enc3 for the formerly called enc1l gene in zebrafish, and Xenc-1 and Xenc-3 for the Xenopus genes previously referred to as Xenc-3 and Xenc-1, respectively ( fig. 1B).

body_text.text: 1B) shows a tight clustering within the three individual subgroups of gnathostome ENC genes (ENC1, -2, and -3).
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: Monophyly of gnathostome sequences for ENC1 (89/0.81), ENC2 (88/1.00), and ENC3 (95/1.00) is inferred (all support values are shown in order, bootstrap probabilities in the ML analysis and Bayesian posterior probabilities; fig. 1B).
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: The three cyclostome ENC genes form an independent group (48/0.65; fig. 1B).
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: The high support (97/1.00) for the clustering of the sea lamprey P. marinus ENC-A with inshore hagfish E. burgeri ENC-A implies their orthology (fig. 1B).
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: The relationship between this cyclostome gene cluster to the three gnathostome ENC subgroups was not unambiguously inferred.
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: The ML tree suggests a closer relationship of gnathostome ENC1 and -3 genes (bootstrap support for their clustering, 27; fig. 1B) to cyclostome ENC genes (bootstrap support, 27; fig. 1B) than to gnathostome ENC2 genes.
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: The topology of the Bayesian analysis inferred a clustering of gnathostome ENC2 and -3 subgroups (posterior probability for their clustering, 0.99; fig. 1B) but did not resolve the trichotomy between this cluster, the ENC1 subgroup, and the group of cyclostome genes.
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: This uncertainty of the phylogenetic position of cyclostome ENC genes demands alternative approaches such as synteny analysis (see below).
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: The exact timings of duplications of the entire genomic region, and thus the ENC gene family, can be pinned down by analyzing the phylogenetic trajectories of neighboring gene families.
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: Is There an Invertebrate Ortholog of the ENC Gene?
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: A comprehensive phylogenetic tree was inferred to investigate the relationships of the ENC group of genes to the rest of the KLHL superfamily.
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: This phylogenetic analysis resulted in a close relationship between the vertebrate ENC genes to other genes in the KLHL superfamily, for example, KLHL29 and KLHL30 (supplementary fig. S1, Supplementary Material online).
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: The vast number of sequences was reduced to a data set including only human, zebrafish, D. melanogaster, C. intestinalis, and C. savignyi genes, and a phylogenetic tree was inferred.
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: Based on this comprehensive phylogenetic tree, a subset containing the ENC gene family was selected for further analysis.
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: Sequences of diverse invertebrates were added to this reduced data set, and their position in the tree relative to the ENC gene family was examined ( fig. 2).
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: One B. floridae gene (XP_002612442 in NCBI) was placed close to the ENC group of proteins in the ML analysis ( fig. 2).
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: However, this clustering was only weakly supported (bootstrap probability, 37) and was not supported by the Bayesian tree inference ( fig. 2).
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: Additionally, a BlastP search of the B. floridae candidate protein sequence in vertebrates (nonredundant protein sequences in NCBI) revealed its highest similarity to kelch-like protein 24 (KLHL24) instead of the ENC genes.
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: The scaffold57 in the B. floridae genome assembly (version 1) harboring this B. floridae gene does not contain any orthologs of the genes surrounding ENC genes in the chicken genome (supplementary table S4, Supplementary Material online).
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: Taken together, our analyses did not particularly support the orthology of this B. floridae gene (XP_002612442) to the vertebrate ENC genes.
body_text.section: Identification of ENC Genes in Diverse Nontetrapod Species

body_text.text: Our molecular phylogenetic analysis suggested the absence of the ENC3 ortholog in eutherians and possibly in lepidosaurs ( fig. 1B).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: Because of sparse sequence information in the lepidosaurian lineage (genome-wide information only exists for the green anole and the Burmese python [Castoe et al. 2011]), the absence of ENC3 in this taxon is highly speculative at this time point.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: The absence of ENC3 in eutherians was confirmed by exhaustive TBlastN searches in eutherian genome assemblies using nonmammalian ENC3 peptide sequences as queries.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: We aimed to determine whether this absence is best explained by a single-gene loss or a large-scale deletion involving substantial parts of the chromosome or even the whole chromosome.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: For this purpose, we examined whether gene orders are conserved between chicken chromosome 28 containing ENC3 and their orthologs in the human genome.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: In the region flanking ENC3 (1 Mb both up-and downstream), we identified 62 chicken protein-coding genes that possess orthologs in the human genome, and 58 of these are located on human chromosome 19.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: More precisely, they are concentrated in two distinct regions ( fig. 3).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: This dense gene-by-gene orthology between these two chromosomes strongly suggests that they are derived from the same ancestral chromosome.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: Despite several rearrangements, the gene order is well conserved ( fig. 3).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: Thus, a large-scale loss event in the lineage leading to eutherians is not supported.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: It is more likely that the ENC3 gene was lost in this lineage in a single-gene deletion that did not affect the surrounding genes.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: We also attempted to determine the scale of the putative ENC3 loss in lepidosaurs by performing the corresponding analysis between the chicken genomic region containing ENC3 and the orthologous genomic region in the green anole, Anolis carolinensis.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: However, the orthologs of the   FIG. 4.-Continued of ENC-flanking genes is shown for chromosomes that lack an ENC gene, namely chromosomes 8 and 25.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: (B) Gene-by-gene paralogies among the quadruplicated genomic regions are highlighted with diagonal lines: gray lines for two paralogs and blue lines for three paralogs.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: Note that the fourth chromosome of the ancestral quartet was split into two chromosomes (chromosomes 8 and 25).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: The fourth ENC gene presumably got lost during evolution but was originally located on an ancestral genomic region from which both chromosome 8 or 25 are derived.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: chr.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: , chromosome; Mb, mega base pairs.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: chicken ENC3-neighboring genes were identified on unassembled small contigs.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: Thus, the current assembly of the A. carolinensis genome does not allow us to draw any conclusions about the scale of the putative loss of ENC3.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: Did ENC1, -2, and -3 Arise through the 2R-WGD?
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: In addition to the molecular phylogenetic analysis, we addressed the question of the timing of the ENC gene family diversification by investigating the conserved gene order between chicken genomic regions containing ENC1, -2, and -3.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: The chicken genome was selected for this purpose because it still retains the ENC3 ortholog (unlike eutherians), and it experienced no additional genome duplication (unlike teleosts).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: The comparisons between the three genomic regions revealed 47 flanking gene families whose pattern of diversification matches the expected 2R-WGD pattern ( fig. 4).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: Additionally, the hypothetical fourth chromosome of the initial 2R-WGD quartet was identified: 15 gene families feature one of the 2R-WGD quartets on chromosome 8 or 25 ( fig. 4).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: The identification of these two chromosomes is not surprising because genome-wide synteny analyses between human and chicken revealed that chicken chromosomes 8 and 25 are orthologous to human chromosome 1 (International Chicken Genome Sequencing Consortium 2004; Voss et al. 2011).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: This is best explained by chromosome fission in the lineage leading to chicken that gave rise to chromosomes 8 and 25.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: Embryonic Expression Patterns of Catshark ENC1 and Zebrafish ENC1, -2, and -3
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: Here, we report the expression patterns of the ENC1 gene in the small-spotted catshark and enc1, -2, and -3 in zebrafish.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: We performed in situ hybridizations on histological samples of embryos of the small-spotted catshark and whole-mount in situ hybridizations on developing zebrafish.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: Both 5 0 -and 3 0 -riboprobes for the catshark ENC1 gene (see Materials and Methods) yielded the same result, and the expression patterns shown in figure 5 were obtained using riboprobes prepared with the 3 0 -end cDNAs.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: Our analysis on catshark embryos at intermediate (stages 26.5-28) and late stages (stages 30-35) of development did not detect any significant expression signal outside the central nervous system (fig. 5).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: The upregulation was first detected in embryos at stage 26.5, when the expression signal was the most intensified in the corpus cerebelli, the hypothalamus (particularly in the nucleus lobi lateralis), the hindbrain, and a putative sensory patch of the otic vesicle ( fig. 5B-E).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: At stage 30, ENC1 is expressed in the superficial region of the cerebellum, midbrain, and telencephalon ( fig. 5G and H).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: The expression in the telencephalon was primarily restricted to the primordial plexiform layer.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: ENC1 is expressed in the developing nucleus in the hypothalamus (nucleus lobi lateralis) but not in the neurohypophysis.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: At stage 33, ENC1 is strongly expressed in a specific layer of the optic tectum (dorsal part of the midbrain), pallium (dorsal part of the telencephalon), and a specific part of the diencephalon (presumably prosomere 2; fig. 5J-L).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: From this stage on it is evident that ENC1 transcripts in the telencephalon are restricted to the pallium and absent from the subpallium (ventral part of the telencephalon).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: At stage 35, ENC1 is expressed in the dorsal side of the telencephalon (pars superficialis anterior, pars superficialis aposteric, and area periventricularis pallialis) and the choroid plexus, which is the only nonneural expression domain of this gene ( fig. 5M and N).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: The expression patterns of the three zebrafish enc genes shown in figure 6 were obtained with riboprobes spanning the 3 0 -UTR and substantial parts of the coding region.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: We found significant expression of all three zebrafish enc genes (enc1, -2, and -3) in developmental stages ranging from 12 to 24 hpf ( fig. 6).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: At early stages of development (14 and 16 hpf; fig. 6A, B, and E), enc1 transcripts are localized in ventral parts of the forebrain, optic vesicle, distinct parts of the hindbrain, newly formed somites, and the tail bud.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: The enc1 expression in the outgrowing tail bud is found in a broad domain of mesenchyme ( fig. 6A'').
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: Double stainings with egr2b, a marker gene for rhombomeres 3 and 5, revealed that both signals overlap in the hindbrain region.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: Thus, the enc1 expression in the hindbrain is also restricted to rhombomeres 3 and 5 ( fig. 6C and D).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: At later developmental stages (24 hpf, fig. 6F and G), the expression of enc1 in the brain persists but does not extend to the anterior most part of the brain.
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: The tail bud expression is reduced to a small domain of the tip of the tail (fig. 6F).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: We detected the expression of enc2 at 12 hpf in anterior parts of the developing brain, distinct parts of the hindbrain, the midline of the posterior trunk, and the tail bud ( fig. 6H and I).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: The expression domain in the hindbrain strongly resembles the expression of enc1 and is most likely also localized in the rhombomeres 3 and 5 ( fig. 6H' and I).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: At 24 hpf, enc2 transcripts are found in the entire anterior part of the central nervous system and a weak expression signal was detected in the tail bud ( fig. 6J).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: Expression signals of enc3 at 16 hpf were found in the tail bud and a specific part of the hindbrain (fig. 6K).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: A dorsal view revealed that the expression in the hindbrain is localized in two lateral structures ( fig. 6L).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: At 24 hpf, expression signal of enc3 is restricted to specific parts of the hindbrain (fig. 6M).
body_text.section: Scale of the Putative Loss of the ENC3 Gene

body_text.text: The ENC Gene Repertoire in Vertebrates Our survey in public databases (including databases derived from individual genome sequencing projects), as well as PCR screens, revealed the presence of three ENC subgroups (ENC1, -2, and -3) in jawed vertebrates, two ENC genes in the sea lamprey (ENC-A and -B), and one in a hagfish (ENC-A).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: An alignment of deduced amino acid sequences of ENC genes revealed a high level of conservation of some key residues ) Expression signals in the hindbrain are maintained at this level, and expression in a putative sensory patch of the otic vesicle (ov) is detected.
body_text.section: Discussion
Discussion

body_text.text: ENC1 is expressed in the outermost layer of the midbrain (mb).
body_text.section: Discussion
Discussion

body_text.text: ENC1 transcripts are located in the corpus cerebelli, the midbrain, and the primordial plexiform layer of the telencephalon (tel).
body_text.section: Discussion
Discussion

body_text.text: ENC1 transcripts are localized in one specific layer of the optic tectum (ot) and specific regions of the pallium (p).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: No expression signal was detected ( fig. 1A).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Therefore, we assume that the structure of ENC proteins is conserved among vertebrates.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Our phylogenetic analysis clearly supported the individual clusters of three distinct gnathostome ENC subgroups, namely  ENC1, -2, and -3 (fig. 1B).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: These three subgroups show uniform rates of evolution indicated by comparable branch lengths.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Interestingly, we do not detect any additional gene in teleost fish generated in the TSGD (Meyer and Van de Peer 2005).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: This observation can be best explained through a secondary gene loss of one ENC paralog derived from this third round of WGD before the radiation of teleosts.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: It is also noteworthy that we did not find any ENC2 gene in multiple chondrichthyan species.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Further sequence data of this taxon are needed to confirm a possible loss of chondrichthyan ENC2.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The ENC gene family is a member of the kelch repeat superfamily (supplementary fig. S1, Supplementary Material online) and shares the conserved BTB/POZ domain and the kelch repeats with other members ( fig. 1A).
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: Our database mining and molecular phylogenetic analysis did not identify any apparent ENC ortholog in invertebrates ( fig. 2; supplementary  table S4, Supplementary Material online).
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: One possible explanation for the alleged absence of invertebrate ENC orthologs might be that they were secondarily lost in invertebrates.
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: However, this assumption would require multiple independent gene losses in diverse invertebrate lineages.
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: Alternatively, this absence can be explained by an elevated evolutionary rate of the ENC gene in the lineage leading to vertebrates erasing significant phylogenetic signals from their sequences ( fig. 7).
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: In molecular phylogenies of many gene families, the branch of the lineage leading to vertebrate genes tends to be elongated for the evolutionary time that elapsed for that period.
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: However, the rate of sequence evolution could still be in the range of sufficient gradualism to allow identification of orthology.
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: In contrast, the evolutionary rate of the ENC gene family might have been beyond gradualism, resulting in saltatory sequence change.
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: As a consequence, orthology of vertebrate ENC genes to their counterparts in invertebrates might be no longer traceable with conventional phylogenetic methods based on overall sequence similarity.
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: We used the B. floridae gene "XP_002612442" to root the tree, although it has not been revealed to be orthologous to vertebrate ENC genes ( fig. 1B).
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: However, the placement of a root to the tree allowed us to address the question about the relationship between cyclostome and gnathostome ENC genes.
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: In this study, we identified three ENC homologs of cyclostomes (hagfish and lamprey) that occupy a key phylogenetic position in addressing early vertebrate evolution.
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: In our phylogenetic analysis, the position of the cyclostome ENC genes remains poorly resolved, and no clear orthology to any gnathostome ENC subgroup was confidently suggested (fig. 1B).
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: Depending on the method we applied, alternative scenarios are conceivable, regarding the diversification pattern within the ENC gene family.
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: This unreliability of the molecular phylogeny is enhanced by unclear timing of WGDs (Kuraku et al. 2009).
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: One scenario in which the three jawed vertebrate ENC subgroups originated through gnathostome-specific gene duplications would result in a clustering of all gnathostome ENC genes with the exclusion of cyclostome ENC genes.
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: Our data do not suggest this scenario ( fig. 1B).
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: A second possibility based on the 2R-WGD is that the group of cyclostome ENC genes is orthologous to one particular gnathostome ENC subgroup.
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: We did not observe any marked affinity of cyclostome ENC genes to a single gnathostome ENC subgroup.
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: The third possible scenario based on the 2R-WGD is that cyclostomes are the only vertebrate group retaining the fourth ENC subtype, the hypothetical ENC4 gene.
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: This scenario would result in a tree topology inferred by the ML method ( fig. 1B), if not only the expected ((A,B),(C,D)) but also a (A,(B,(C,D))) topology is admitted as evidence for a 1-2-4 pattern.
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: Also, the phylogeny inferred by the Bayesian method suggests this scenario ( fig. 1B).
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: Thus, our phylogenetic analysis suggests that cyclostome ENC genes are remnants of the fourth ENC subtype that is absent from gnathostome genomes ( fig. 7).
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: All scenarios imply an additional cyclostome-specific duplication of the ancestral ENC4 gene resulting in E. burgeri ENC-A, P. marinus ENC-A and ENC-B followed by a secondary gene loss or nonidentification of the ENC-B gene in hagfish ( fig. 7).
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: It was previously proposed that frequent clustering of cyclostome sequences in molecular phylogenetic trees might be caused by a systematic artifact resulting from their unique sequence properties (Qiu et al. 2011).
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: More sequence data of cyclostomes could potentially provide a higher resolution of the ENC gene phylogeny.
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: Putative ENC3 Gene Loss in the Eutherian Lineage Our molecular phylogenetic analysis suggested the absence of ENC3 genes in eutherians and possibly in lepidosaurs ( fig. 1B).
body_text.section: Origin of the ENC Gene Family

body_text.text: The secondary loss of the ENC3 gene in the lepidosaur lineage cannot be inferred with high confidence because of sparse sequence information in this lineage.
body_text.section: FIG. 5.-Continued

body_text.text: Our attempt to trace conserved synteny between the chicken ENC3-containing genomic region and the green anole genome failed because of insufficient assembly continuity of the latter genome.
body_text.section: FIG. 5.-Continued

body_text.text: In contrast, a considerably large number of eutherian genomes have been sequenced, and this speaks in favor of a secondary gene loss instead of incomplete genome sequencing.
body_text.section: FIG. 5.-Continued

body_text.text: Other examples of genes that are absent from mammalian genomes, and therefore remained unidentified until recently, include the Bmp16 gene (Feiner et al. 2009), the Edn4 gene (Braasch et al. 2009), the Pdx2 gene (Mulley and Holland 2010), and the Hox14 gene (Powers and Amemiya 2004).
body_text.section: FIG. 5.-Continued

body_text.text: To address whether the presumed absence of ENC3 in this lineage was caused by a small-scale secondary loss or rather a large-scale deletion, we searched for conserved synteny between the chicken chromosomal region containing ENC and the human genome.
body_text.section: FIG. 5.-Continued

body_text.text: We identified an array of orthologous genes shared between chicken chromosome 28 and human chromosome 19 ( fig. 3), as previously suggested by macrosynteny data (International Chicken Genome Sequencing Consortium 2004).
body_text.section: FIG. 5.-Continued

body_text.text: The fact that orthologs of chicken ENC3neighboring genes are present in the human genome suggests a single-gene loss of ENC3 in the common ancestor of eutherians.
body_text.section: FIG. 5.-Continued

body_text.text: It is interesting to investigate in future work what impact the loss of the ENC3 ortholog had on associated pathways and to what extent ENC1 and -2 might have possibly compensated the roles of ENC3.
body_text.section: FIG. 5.-Continued

body_text.text: By performing intragenomic comparison in chicken, we identified a quartet of chromosomes containing ENC1, -2, and -3 and the region that presumably erstwhile harbored the putative fourth paralog (fig. 4).
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: The patterns and timings of duplications in neighboring gene families lend support to the hypothesis that ENC1, -2, and -3 are derived from the 2R-WGD early in vertebrate evolution (Dehal and Boore 2005;Kasahara 2007;Putnam et al. 2008).
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: The precise timing of the 2R-WGD was revealed to be after the split of the invertebrate lineages but before the divergence between cyclostomes and gnathostomes (Kuraku et al. 2009).
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: Quartets of chromosomes showing conserved synteny have been used as evidence of the 2R-WGD (Lundin 1993;Holland et al. 1994;Sidow 1996;Spring 1997).
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: It was previously shown that chicken chromosomes 8, 10, 17, 28, W, and Z were derived from one single chromosome in the hypothetical karyotype of the vertebrate ancestor (Nakatani et al. 2007).
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: This set of corresponding chromosomes after the 2R-WGD does not form a quartet but a sextet, possibly -Scenario describing the diversification of the ENC gene family.
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: This schematic gene tree illustrates the saltatory evolution of the ENC gene family in the lineage leading to vertebrates.
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: At the base of vertebrate radiation, the ancestral ENC gene was quadruplicated in the 2R-WGD giving rise to ENC1-3 as well as the fourth duplicate hypothetically designated ENC4.
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: No obvious cyclostome ortholog of gnathostome ENC1-3 was identified to date, which is best explained by their secondary losses in the cyclostome lineage.
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: The hypothetical ENC4 gene presumably was secondarily lost in the lineage leading to gnathostomes and duplicated in cyclostomes giving rise to ENC-A and -B followed by presumed gene loss of ENC-B in hagfish.
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: This hypothetical scheme is deduced from the phylogenetic trees shown in figures 1B and 2.
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: Red crosses indicate inferred secondary gene losses, and question marks indicate uncertainty of the loss because of incomplete sequence information.
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: because of chromosome fission after the first round of duplication (Nakatani et al. 2007).
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: Our analysis focusing only on parts of the chromosomes harboring ENC genes identified the same set of chromosomes with the exception of chromosome 25, instead of W and 17 ( fig. 4).
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: More precisely, our analysis suggested that chromosomes 25 and 8 are derived from one proto-chromosome separated by fission ( fig. 4).
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: The incongruence is best explained by different resolution of our study compared with that of Nakatani et al. (2007).
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: Although we focused on a 20-Mb region flanking the ENC genes, the previous study employed fewer markers in the genomic region of our interest (Nakatani et al. 2007).
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: This is why our study provided a higher resolution to detect microlevel genomic rearrangements relevant for ENC gene family evolution ( fig. 4).
body_text.section: Expansion of the ENC Gene Family in 2R-WGD

body_text.text: Chondrichthyans occupy a key phylogenetic position serving as outgroup to osteichthyans (including teleosts and tetrapods).
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: Comparisons of features between chondrichthyans and osteichthyans allow us to reconstruct the ancestral state of jawed vertebrates.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: Our study advances the knowledge on both of these major gnathostome lineages by providing the first report of ENC1 expression patterns in a chondrichthyan and expression profiles of all three enc genes in a teleost.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: Expression analysis of the full set of ENC genes in a single species was hitherto only performed in the amphibian X. laevis (Haigo et al. 2003).
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: Detailed cross-species comparisons need to be drawn with caution, and only homologous structures of corresponding developmental stages can provide meaningful insights into the evolution of expression patterns and their regulation.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: In this respect, the expression patterns we obtained in the small-spotted catshark S. canicula and the zebrafish are difficult to compare to Xenc-1 to -3 because Haigo et al. (2003) mainly focused on earlier developmental stages of X. laevis.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: In addition, the literature does not contain any detailed description of Xenc expression domains in the developing brain as Garcia-Calero and Puelles (2009) and Hernandez et al. (1997) published for chicken (only telencephalon) and mouse ENC1, respectively.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: The ENC1 expression in the catshark prosencephalon (primordial plexiform layer of telencephalon and specific parts of the pallium; see fig. 5) has also been described for chicken (Garcia-Calero and Puelles 2009) and mouse (Hernandez et al. 1997).
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: In addition, ENC1 is expressed in diencephalon (hypothalamus and prosomere 2 of the diencephalon), mesencephalon (optic tectum), and rhombencephalon (corpus cerebelli and its caudal extension to the neural tube) of catshark ( fig. 5) and mouse (Hernandez et al. 1997).
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: This suggests that the roles of ENC1 in brain patterning were already established in the last common ancestor of chondrichthyans and osteichthyans.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: Although deep homology between all bilaterian brains has been suggested (reviewed in Hirth 2010; see also Northcutt 2012 and references therein; Strausfeld and Hirth 2013), integrative centers such as the telencephalon have not been identified in nonvertebrate chordates (Wicht and Lacalli 2005;see also Pani et al. 2012).
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: Thus, well-organized brain structures based on the expansion of the neural tube should be regarded as a vertebrate novelty.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: Its origin in the earliest phase of vertebrate evolution coincides with the establishment of the ENC gene family involved in brain patterning.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: It is intriguing to corroborate if the emergence of this gene family contributed to the vertebrate novelty of the tripartite brain.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: We also identified differences in expression patterns suggesting lineage-specific changes in developmental programs.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: ENC1 expression in presomitic mesoderm, the only expression domain outside the nervous system, and dorsal root ganglia of mouse embryos (Hernandez et al. 1997) have not been observed in zebrafish ( fig. 6A-G) and Xenopus (Haigo et al. 2003).
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: Vice versa, expression signals of ENC1 in the tail bud of zebrafish ( fig. 6A-F) and somites of zebrafish ( fig. 6A-E) and Xenopus (Haigo et al. 2003) are absent from the developing mouse (Hernandez et al. 1997).
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: Thus, these expression domains of ENC1 were secondarily modified in the respective lineages.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: We identified a nonneural expression of ENC1 in the choroid plexus of a catshark embryo at stage 35 ( fig. 7N) that has not been identified in any other species to date.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: The choroid plexus potentially is an ancestral jawed vertebrate ENC1 expression domain that was lost in the lineage leading to osteichthyans or, more parsimoniously, represents an autapomorphic feature of chondrichthyans.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: The ENC1 expression in the optic vesicle is shared between zebrafish ( fig. 6A and B), Xenopus, and mouse but is not observed in catshark embryos ( fig. 5) and presumably has been established in the common ancestor of osteichthyans.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: Within osteichthyans, expression data of ENC2 and -3 genes as well as ENC1 allow inferences of possible shuffling of expression domains.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: Previously, the full set of ENC1, -2, and -3 genes has been investigated in X. laevis (Haigo et al. 2003), and enc3 expression was analyzed in the zebrafish Danio rerio (Bradford et al. 2011;Qian et al. 2013).
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: Our study describing expression patterns of zebrafish enc1, -2, and -3 combined with a reliable orthology assignment ( fig.  1B) allows a solid reconstruction of the evolution of expression domains within osteichthyans.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: During tailbud stages, all three Xenopus ENC genes are expressed in the neural tube and the otic vesicle, and only ENC1 is expressed in the tail bud.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: In addition, each gene possesses specific expression domains, such as the dorsal fin, the cement gland, and the pronephric anlage for ENC1 (Xenc-3), ENC2, and ENC3 (Xenc-1), respectively.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: In comparable stages of zebrafish (~16 hpf), all three enc genes are commonly expressed in the tail bud and the developing brain ( fig. 6).
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: Each zebrafish enc gene also has specific expression domains such as somites, midline expression (presumably corresponding to the neural tube), and specific parts of the hindbrain for enc1, -2, and -3, respectively ( fig. 6A, I, and K).
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: The comparison of the overlap between expression domains of individual ENC genes between zebrafish and Xenopus reveals that most likely a different set of genes retained the ancestral expression domains: only Xenopus ENC1, but all three zebrafish enc genes retained expression in the tail bud ( fig. 6A, H, and K), and Xenopus ENC1 and -2, but only zebrafish enc1 retained the somite-specific expression domain (fig. 6A).
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: The ENC1 gene is expressed in a more pleiotropic manner than its sister genes ENC2 and ENC3 in zebrafish ( fig. 6) and Xenopus (Haigo et al. 2003), suggesting its prevalent role in the developing nervous system.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: The expression of enc1 and -2 in the rhombomeres 3 and 5 that we observed in zebrafish is absent from Xenopus (Haigo et al. 2003).
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: However, the catshark ENC1 gene also showed expression in the hindbrain ( fig. 5B-E and L).
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: Thus, the role of ENC1 in the developing hindbrain might be conserved between chondrichthyans and teleosts.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: Our comparison suggests a shuffling of expression domains among ENC1, -2, and -3 in osteichthyans.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: However, without expression data of ENC2 and -3 in a more basal lineage, for example, chondrichthyans, we cannot decide whether losses or gains in the lineages leading to osteichthyans or actinopterygians caused these differences in expression profiles.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: An intriguing question about possible shuffling of ENC expression domains also within tetrapods is currently elusive because of missing ENC2 expression data in mammals and the presumed absence of ENC3 in eutherians.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: Our expression analysis in the small-spotted catshark S. canicula suggests conserved developmental roles of ENC1 in brain patterning during jawed vertebrate evolution.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: The comparison of the expression profiles we gained for zebrafish enc1, -2, and -3 genes revealed a differential loss of ancestral expression domains between 2Rderived paralogs.
body_text.section: Conserved Role of ENC Genes in Brain Patterning

body_text.text: It is usually the case that we can identify invertebrate orthologs of vertebrate gene families even though they experienced secondary events such as WGDs in the vertebrate lineage.
body_text.section: Perspectives

body_text.text: Many of such genes are additional copies of existing genes derived from the WGDs.
body_text.section: Perspectives

body_text.text: Otherwise, some genes arose de novo at the base of vertebrate evolution.
body_text.section: Perspectives

body_text.text: Interestingly, the ENC family does not belong to these categories, possibly because of the saltatory evolution of the ancestral ENC gene early in the vertebrate lineage.
body_text.section: Perspectives

body_text.text: This unique feature was masked for a long time by a lack of whole-genome sequences of invertebrates.
body_text.section: Perspectives

body_text.text: To our knowledge, Satb1/2 genes (Nechanitzky et al. 2012) in the homeobox-containing gene family belong to this category (Burglin and Cassata 2002;Zhong et al. 2008).
body_text.section: Perspectives

body_text.text: Our finding renders an insightful theme for future genome-wide studies to reveal more longstanding genes that experienced saltatory evolution at the emergence of vertebrates and examine their contribution to phenotypic characters unique to vertebrates.
body_text.section: Perspectives
